abstracts.cdata!:
The National Emergency Employment
            Program for Rural Access Project for Afghanistan, which
            forms a part of the Government's National Emergency
            Employment Program (NEEP), will assist the Government in
            providing targeted social protection, and improving key
            rural access infrastructure to improve the livelihoods of
            the rural poor in the Government's territory by
            providing: (i) emergency short term employment opportunities
            for the poor on labor-based rural access infrastructure
            improvement subprojects; and (ii) technical assistance for
            the implementation of NEEP. The Credit portion will finance
            the reconstruction of secondary rural access
            infrastructure--primarily bridges. The Grant will finance
            the rehabilitation of tertiary rural access infrastructure
            and technical assistance to the Government for implementing
            its NEEP. The project will comprise two components: A)
            labor-based rural access rehabilitation reconstruction
            subprojects; and, B) technical assistance to support the
            Government's overall NEEP. The Project is expected to
            create a minimum of 6,000,000 unskilled labor days of
            employment, and to rehabilitate a minimum of 2000 km of
            rural roads and 2300 m of bridges. The labor-based
            sub-projects are expected to provide high social returns in
            the short run and contribute to economic progress in the
            long-term. The employment generated will reduce income
            vulnerability levels and create infrastructure which will
            improve access to markets and services. By removing access
            bottlenecks, the project will help integrate the village
            economy with the regional and national markets. The
            technical assistance component will lead to better
            allocation of resources, higher productivity and outputs,
            and help mobilize further donor resources for productive
            employment creation. The project builds upon working
            implementation arrangements, but even so its implementation
            is  expected to be difficult. The security situation could
            deteriorate, derailing reconstruction efforts. This is
            outside the scope of the project design. However, the
            project's modular design will allow activities in one
            or more unstable provinces to cease without stopping work in
            provinces where there are no or few security risks. The
            Credit and Grant are expected to be fully disbursed in a 39
            month period.
